div.head: THE GREAT MYSTERY.
div.p: Directivity is a word not to be found in any lictionary, and yet it sums up in one word the great mystery of the universe-the mystery of Who directs its pulsating life.

Professor G. Henslow uses the word in a most interesting number of the "Hibbert Journal" (Oct.), and says that he is indebted or it to the eminent chemist Prof. A.H Church. "It has long been contended," he says, “that there is no force in a living body which cannot ultimately be identified with the physical forces of the inorganic world or be converted into tbem--chemical, mechanical, electrical, or otherwise. No one disputes this now; but there is something else which cannot De so explained, and that is directivity, and it is my object to trace this property through the world." "Directivity is no force, but a characteristic of life."

To illustrate this he points out that "in every case the food may be the same for a great variety of organisms, as for a multitude of species of plants growing in the same meadow; or when sheep, oxen, horses, and even geese may be feeding on the same grassland. In each case the molecular compounds of the grass are identical, but they find themselves ultimately disposed in very different arrangements in the different animals. This can only be possible, under the influence of directivity, but 'directing differently in each creature. This directivity is therefore a characteristic of life."

"Why," asks Prof. Henslow, "should certain substances be guided to certain places --- salts of line to bones, silica to teeth and claws, phosphates to brain, etc. The molecules are first driven about mechanically in the blood by certain forces ; various chemical combinations are made under the action of other forces; but what directs all the foroes which finally impel the new-nade molecules to take up certain positions over others in the building up of a body ? Directivity is a useful word to express the fact. It commits one to nothing as to its source, but it at least supplies a term to express the analogy between the chemist's mind and Nature's what ?"

Once more he points out that "if a water plant be growing up submerged but reaches the surface of the water and then grows into the air, the whole anatomy at once alters at the water level. If a leaf happen to stand obliquely at the surface so that one half grows under water, the other half developing above it, the former is constructed to be in harmony with a submerged existence, the other half being adapted to live in air. Again, if the hook-like extremities of the tendrils of the Virginia creeper touch a wall, the points at once begin to swell into adhesive pads. What is it which guides the constructive forced to build up the tissues in response to the above external conditions ?' The provisional answer is, Directivity is life."

Prof. Henslow then points out that Haeckel in his "Riddle of the Universe," and other modern rationalists, do not explain this. "They can do no more than assert that it is all done by blind forces; as if forces possessed a sort of consciousness of what they are about and a will “to determine their own motions and directions."

"Are all organic structures the outcome of some Universal Intelligence in some sort of way akin to that in ourselves which every human being is profoundly conscious of possessing l" asks the Professor. "How is the question to be decided ? It seems to depend on the capacity of individual brains as to their power of appreciation of induction."

"In universal directivity there is recognised as immanent an Omnipresent Director as head; to which again, judging by analogy with our own human consciousness of directivity, the result of our will, the induction now super-adds consciousness and will. Because it is inconceivable how these properties of man's psychology can have arisen at all if there bad not been some origination in qualities of a like mind or nature."

"We thus realise conception of God in Nature," concludes Prof. Henslow, "or the Power' of Mr. Herbert Spencer, by direct inductive reasoning. If Haeckel cannot accept this induction, all we can say is that from our point of view his mind must have a 'want.' On the other hand, he will retort, 'Your inductions are all superstitions."

div.head: Nubar's Memorial.
div.p: The public fountain, which Boghng Pasha Nabar is erecting in the Saida Zenab Square, Cairo, in memory of his father, will be inaugurated shortly.

div.head: Balram.
div.p: On the occasion of the Ramadan Bairam which commences on the 7th instant, all Government offices will be closed from the 6th to the 10th instant inclusive.

div.head: The Persian Colony.
div.p: Prince Erfa Ul-Dewleh has been appointed to arbitrate on the dispute, which has broken ont between the members of the Persian Colony in Cairo and their Diplomatic Agent.

div.head: Cum Arabic.
div.p: In yesterday's issue we announced that gum Arabic of a dark quality had been sold at P.T. 118 per cantar. We, however, omitted to mention that this was in the Oldurman market and not at Alexandria, where the present price is P.T. 135 per cantar of 99 lbs.

div.head: Coal Imports.
div.p: Between January 1 and October 31 1,101,664 tons of coal were imported into Egypt, of which 603,308 tons were Welsh 129,422 Nes. castle, 168,762 Yorkshire, 88,225 Scotch and 111,947 other qualities. Daring the corresponding period of last year the imports totalled 1,091,256.

div.head: New Edition of the Koran.
div.p: The Ministry of Public Instruction recently published a new edition of the Koran for the use of the people of Egypt. When it issued from the National Press it was found to be toll of mistakes. It was then revised by the Chancellor of Al Azhar University and ten thousand errors were discovered!

div.head: All Invited.
div.p: Divine Service will be (D. V.) recominenced to morrow, Nov. 3rd at the Sailors' and Soldiers' Institute at 10a.m. Subject of sermon, "The Cities of Refuge and their lesson to the people of Alexandria." Friends of all nationalities who understand the English language will be heartily welcomed. W. Dickins.

div.head: The Tour Eiffel.
div.p: The management of the Tour Eiffel announces the debut this eveining of the celebrated Spanish dancer Pilar de Garcia, of continental fame. Giuntini, whose celerity in transformation is quite extraordinary, has gained a great and deserved success, despite the fact that he neglects the obliteration of the inevitable sign of a strong facial hirsuto growth when he appears on the stage as a inember of the gentler sex.

div.head: Ministry of Finance.
div.p: The Ministry of Finance reminds the public that in accordance with the terms of Art. 9. Decree of March 13, 1884 concerning constructed buildings, the proprietors of such in the localities subjected to the said tax must give notice in writing before the 15th inst. of all buildings as well as the additions or alterations on their present property. The said declarations must be submitted to the Governorat or mondirieh of the locality where the proprietor lives.

div.head: Capture of Thieves.
div.p: Though the searches op to the present for the employé of a well-known Alexandrian firm, who has illegally enriched himself to the extent of about £1,600, have proved fruitless, the police should be grateful to the firm which has suffered. In seeking for the absconder aboard the Khedivial Mail outward steamer the police discovered three thieves of reputo and promptly arrested them. Meanwhile every vessel is carefully watched with a view to catching the man in question, who is still presumably in Alexandria.

div.head: Cairo Church Committee.
div.p: At a meeting of the All Saints' Church Committee, held at the General's house, on Thursday, the 24th of October, General Bullock in the chair, Sir Eldon Goist was elected President in the place of Lord Cromer, resigned ; and Mr. A. P. Rolland was appointed Secretary in the room of Mr. Du Boulay, resigned. All communications concerning the Church should be addressed now to Mr Rolland, at the Church House. This first gathering of the Church Committee to meet the new President and the new Chaplain was a large and representative one, and angers well, we hope, for the interest that will be taken in Church affairs this winter.

div.head: The Rangabe Case.
div.p: The Hellenic Consular Court at Alexandria has recently delivered an important judgment atlecting the divorces pronounced by the Orthodkex Patriarchate between Hellenic sok jects domiciled in Egypt. Mrs. Smaragia Rangabe summoned her husband, Mr. Otho Rangabe before the Consular Court for alimony. The defendant pleaded that the plaintiff's demand for alimony was inadmissible as no matrimonial obligations existed between them now, inasmuch as the Orthodox Patriarchate has dissolved the marriage. The court held that the dissolution of the marriage pronounced by the Patriarchate was null and void and ordered Mr. Rangabé to pay £18 per month as alimony. In matrimonial cases, especially in cases of divorce the Hellenic Civil Tribunal have sole competence of jurisdiction and the main principle therefore must be held to exist in countries where the régime of the capitulations exist. Hellenic subjects dwelling in such countries in order to get a valid decree of divorce must apply to the courts where the husband was last domiciled in Greece, as divorce cases do not come within the jurisdiction of the Consular Courts. Therefore all divorces pronounced by the Oribodox Patriarchate in Egypt between them are null and void.

div.head: THE HARDEN CASE.
div.p: PUBLIC PROSECUTOR AWAKENS.
PRIVATE ACTIONS PENDING.
(Gazette's Special Service.)
London, Saturday.

In connection with the Harden . revelations, which are now absorbing a world wide interest, the Go Dan Public Prosecutor has decided to take libel action against Herr Harden. It is also stated that Prince Eulenberg and Count von Moltke will also take private actions for libel against Maitre Bernstein, who was Harden's advocate in the recent trial. It is the general opinion that further investigation into the allegations of Harden are absolutely necessary, and it is considered that the impending cases will bring to a climax one of the most extraordinary legal actions of the century.

div.head: MESOPOTAMANIAN
div.p: IRRIGATION.
BANK DEPOSITS BY TURKEY. BARRAGE TENDERS INVITED. (Gazette's Special Service.)
London, Saturday.

It is stated that a large sum has been deposited by the Turkish Government in Baghdad at the Imperial Ottoman Bank Agency earmarked for expenditure on the irrigation of Mesopotamia. Tenders have been invited for the construction of an important barrage on the Hindia canal.

div.head: TURKEY AND MONTENEGRO.
div.p: DIFFICULTIES YET UNSOLVED.
(Gazette's Special Service.)
London, Saturday.

No solution has yet been found to the Turco-Montenegrin difficulty. The situation is Aggravated by the recent attack on a Turkish detachment, but there is no disposition on either side to come to a definite rupture. The Montenegrin envoy is still at Constantinople and negotiations are exclusively in the hands of Emperor Nicholas and the Sultan.

div.head: LORD CROMER AS AUTHOR.
div.p: HIS BOOK ON EGYPT.
(Gazette's Special Service.)
London, Saturday.
Lord Cromer has written a book on Egypt which will be published shortly.

div.head: CRIME IN THE PROVINCES.
div.p: A DOUBLE MURDER.
(FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT)
Zagazig, Saturday.

Two sons of a notable of Faccous have been found murdered on their father's property. The police are actively engaged in investigations. The district is greatly agitated by this brutal crime, the motive of which is at present incomprehensible. Up to the time of telegraphing no trace of the murderer of murderers has been found. It is, however, suspected that more than one man is implicated, and the police's attention is directed towards the Bedouins of the district. With overy murder committed discussion not unnaturally involves the wholo question of crime in the provinces and the difficulties of bringing the authors to book. As far as I can judge, the general impression is that more English officials are required in the country districts as resident authorities. First of all there is no question as to their incorruptibility, secondly an order given by them is sure to be carried out to the best of their enbordin. ates' capability, and thirdly their determination to solve a set problem usually ineets with success. We cannot do without the British "bull dog," and, despite the wailings of Mustapha Kamel, the more we have of him the better it will be for Egypt and the Egyptians.

div.head: SUAKIN MINING SYNDICATE.
div.p: The Suakin Mining Syndicate has been developing the Barrahme Mine, held under lease by the Egypt and Sudan Mining Syndicate, in terms of the agreement. Although the operations have not yet resulted in the opening up of any considerable extent of ore-ground, the directors are hopeful that farther shoots of ore similar to the one which was discovered by the Egypt and Sudan Mining Syndicate at the 130 ft. level, and which produced gold-bearing quartz of high value may be met with. To treat the ore already opened up a 5-stamp battery, with the necessary engine power, was sent to the mine in January last and set in operation in Juno. A consignment of gold of the value of £300 was recently received, and a further quantity is expected shortly. This gold has been obtained from the dumps at surface and underground working apart from the rich shoot of ore at and below the 180 f. loval. The superintendent now advises that stoping was about to be commenced on this shoot, and an improved oatlay of gold may consequently be antiolpated. The ayndicato is well provided with funde.

div.head: PROGRESSION OF SOCIALISM
div.p: ROUT OF THE LIBERALS.
GREAT UNIONIST VICTORIES
(Gazette’s Special Service.)
London, Saturday.
In the Municipal elections the Socialist have completely routed the Liberals, who have sustained heavy losses, while grout Unionis victories are recorded.

div.head: FRUITS OF SEDITION.
div.p: EGYPT'S AGITATORS.
SEVERE MEASURES IN PROSPECT.
(Gazette’s Special Service.)
London, Saturday.

Lord Minto's speech on the occasion of passing a bill for the prevention of public and sedations meetings has met with great approval in the home Press. The determination te repress sedition strengthens confidence in Mr. Morley's policy and it is anticipated that similar treatment awaits seditious agitators in Egypt whilst recognising the honesty of the purpose of the educated Egyptians who are desirous of advancing the legitimate claims of their country.

div.head: BOURSE AND BANKING.
div.p: We learn from a reliable source that an application has been made to the British Consul General of Alexandria for the appointment of an official liquidator for the Bourse and Banking Co. of Egypt, Ltd.
We hear that notice has been served upon the voluntary liquidator to appear before the consul on the 12th inst. to show cause why the application for an official liquidator should not be granted.

div.head: APPROACH OF THE SEASON.
div.p: Though it only just November, Cairo already shews signs of the coming season and whereas a few weeks ago one might lunch or dine in comparative solitude even in the most popular hotels, such hotels as are already open present quite an animated appearance now. The Sudan Budget is of course keeping a good many men in town, but apart from these there is quite a fair number of visitors at the hotels, and the accomplished salesmen who frequent the streets at the first appearance of the tourist are already exhibiting their wares and rubbing up their half forgotten English.

And after all why should the tourist shun Egypt until the latter end of November, when the country offers such a perfect climate nearly A month earlier. It may be that the days would strike the stranger as being a little too warm perhaps, but if it is change that they are seeking it will be more readily found in the earlier months of the winter, when dinner is served on the terraces under the naked sky agd the life and colour of the East is really in evidence.

The ordinary tourist who comes out to Egypt in December and leaves again in February or March has really no idea of the drowsy Eastern life at all, and very often leaves with theimpres. sion that after all life here is much the same as life in Europe, except perhaps that the latter possesses charms of cleanliness which the former Jacks. It is the old story of Padgett M.P., as year by year the tourist comes, lingers bis few months, and vanishes before tho true life of the country, the sun wakes into being
"Where is your heat ?” said he
“Coming", said I to Padgett,
“Skittles”, said Padgett M.P.

He visits the bazaars and is cheated by rascals of his own spoiling, and who talk pigeon English and invent fairly tales for his benefit. He returns to his hotel, replete with every European comfort, and he eventually leaves the country as ignorant of the true nature of the place and people as when he arrived. Indeed, he is usually more ignorant, for he has received impressions which no power on earth will rid him of, ideas which he fondly imagines he has assimilated from personal observation, but which have in reality been grafted into bis mind by the dragoman who accompanied him in his wanderings.
With a very few exceptions it is the case of "Pagett M. P." over again
"Where is your heat ?” said he
“Coming", said I to Padgett,
“Skittles”, said Padgett M.P.
the hasty impressions of a few weeks spent for the most part in the company of a dragoman in preference to the experience of years gained to residents in the country.

Let the tourist for his own benefit, come out and study the conditions which obtain before the place is Buropeanized both in climate and manners, let him wander amongst the Natives alone, without a dragoman at his side to proclaim his helplessness to all concerned, and he will find that life in Cairo is of a very different nature to that which presents itself to the eyes of the visitor who comes here to "do" the sights.

CAIRO & ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: THE STRUGGLE OF THE PARTIES.
div.p: The intestine disputas of the various sections of the Nationaliuta appear to be inoressing it virulence, for the speech of Mustapha Pasha Kamel at the Zinnia Theatre has resulted in exasperating rather than mollifying the other groups. Some of the Nationalista are spending money freely to get rid of their once powerful chief and agents are going about the country offering P.T. 120 to each native who will sign a petition against him. The statement is made in Kamel's own organ, which would be inclined to minimise rather than exaggerate the agitation against him. The "Egyptian Standard of yesterday's date contained the following paragraph, beaded "A Carious Intrigue" :

The "Lews" of yesterday published a communication from a notable of Manaura, which confirms a telegram sent the previous day, and in which he states that for some time past an individual, delegated by a well known native journalist in Cairo, has been endeavour ing to secure signatures, on a promise of 120 P.T. to each signatory, to a document directed against the "Lewa" and its proprietor. We think that this intriguer is likely to find himself one day hoist with his own petard. Sach tactics neither discourage nor frighten us."

While these tactics are being pursued in the towns and villages, the attacks in the other Nationalist newspapers against Kamel continue with unabated force. The Moderate Nationalist section of the vernacular Moslem Press, represented by "Al Moryad" and "Al Minbar", never relar their efforts to expose the hollowness of Kamol's pretentions. A contributor to the latter newspaper, Mohamed el-Hai, writes :

"I ought to mention that the unanimous opinion of the thoughtful section of the Egyptian nation is that this young man, Mustapha Kamel, has become subject to powerful illusions and that these illusions of his will in the end be disastrous to himself or to the nation and probably to both together."

div.head: THE PARTY OF THE NATION.
div.p: While the Moderate Nationalists are fighting Kamel and his followers, a fierce conflict is being carried on in another part of the field of battle between the Party of the Nation and the Egyptian Liberals. The trouble has arisen because the Cairo correspondent of the "Manchester Guardian" in writing to that newspaper stated that the various points in the political programmes of the Party of the Nation and the Egyptian Liberals were so much alike that it was strange that a fusion of the two sects had not taken place. Now to declare that any of the pro. grammes of the various political parties in Egypt bears the slightest resemblance to any of the others, is an insult of the most bitter character, for each party prides itself on being original. As soon as the copy of the "Manchester Guardian" containing this article arrived in Egypt, the organ of the Party of the Nation, “Al Garida" became very annoyed that anybody should venture to suggest that its programine had the slightest affinity with the tenets of the Egyptinn Liberals. It declared that the Party of the Nation was in its very essence utterly unconnected with any of the dogma, forming part of the creed of the Egyptian Liberals, for the Party of the Nation insisted on the independence and self-governinent of Egypt, while that the Egyptian Liberals actually accepted and recognised the Occupation. Moreover the Liberals were only an imaginary party whereas the Party of the Nation was the only real and genuine political party in the whole country. As El Sayed Hassan Moussa EI Akkad had recently declared in the columns of Mustapha Pasha Kamel's organ that the Party of the Nation only existed in the imagination of a few individuals, the object of this taunt no doubt thought that it would be a good stroke of policy to pass it on to the Liberals.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN LIBERALS.
div.p: Of course these terrible calumnies worked up the Egyptian Liberals to a pitch of exasperation and as much ink has of late been spilt over this squabble as has been the case in the struggle between the Moderate Nationalists and Kamer's party. The Leader of the Liberals, Mohamed Bey Wahid, at once took up the challenge and issued a manifesto wherein be declared that the policy of the Party of the Nation was as fantastic as the party itself. He went on to state that neither his party nor the Party of the Nation could ignore the fact that the English were in Egypt and that it was not possible for them to order the English to at once evacuate the country. After attempt.ing to prove at great length that the arguments of the Party of the Nation were all absolutely fallacions be appended to his manifesto two articles of the programme of the Egyptian Liberals wherein it was openly declared that the Liberals claimed the independence and autonomy of Egypt.

The statement that neither the Party of the Nation nor the Egyptian Liberals Are able to ignore the fact that the English are in Egypt has been received with some interest, and the announcement must be welcomed as an original contribution to local politics, for it has raised a problem which still awaits solution. Bron Kamol does not ignore the fact of the English being in Egypt but accepts it as an unnecessary evil. Whether the Party of the Nation can draw up a political programme which will completely ignore this disagreeable fact, remains to be seen, but at any rate the Egyptian Liberals leader declares it to be an impossibility.

div.head: COPTIC OPINION.
div.p: The Copts, who were specially urged by Kamol in his Zizinia speech to join with the Moslems under his leadership, seems to be very slack in making any reply. The leading Coptio organ, "Al Watan," in an article on the state of political parties in Egypt, remarks :-

"Our friends are still hammering at the question of Egyptian parties and their names To one who reads the comments of our Arabic contemporaries on this subject nothing is clearer than the fact that political parties in this country are mere names and that the whole talk about there parties sounds like the vague and meaningless promise of the old Tork. There is no doubt, a vast number of low-class illiterates and simple-minded patriots who believe that Mustafa Pasha Kamel is the incarnation of statesmanship and patriotism and who are bis followers. On the other hand it may be safely asserted that among the higher classen the majority is anti-Kamelite. The Copta, almost to a man, are moderates on the lines of AlWatan; while the Syrians, who after the Copts are the strongest native element in Egypt are advocates of the dogma of political moderation As expounded by "Al-Mokattam" with which we share views on most of our questions. Among the Mohamedans it cannot be denied that the majority is with the leader of low class politics, but & considerable number of notables side with "Al-Garida," "Al-Minbar," and other newspapers of this variety. As these papers are unsettled and ancoufirmed in their professed political faith we can see no wonder in the apparent confusion and vagueness of their - political programmes. Some of these papers shew irreconcilable enmity to the supporters of their own party for no reason save the innate fanaticism of their editors and the false natore of their political moderation. One has only to read "Al-Garida," "Al-Moayad," "Al-Minbar" to see this abominable fraud in our party politics. These three papers profess now to be moderates on the lines of "Al-Mok. attam," "Misr," and "Al-Watan". There is no essential difference between our side and theirs on any great question affecting general interests in Egypt. Yet these three Mohamedan papers cannot bide their great hatred to the three papers owned by Christians. They are Actually fighting us although they declare to be of our own opinion now. They reproduce articles in support of their views but they never reproduce anything from "Al-Mokattam," "Misr," or "Al Watan."Surely we have ample reason for losing all faith in their sincerity and in the firm nature of their political creed."

div.head: EGYPT'S CONSTITUTIONAL INSTITUTIONS.
div.p: A work, which is sure to cause some discussion in Egypt, is to be published in London shortly. It deals with constitutional institutions in this country and the author is Mr. Pox-Bourne, of the Aborigines Protection Society. The work will be to a large extent retrospective, tracing the history of the condominium, Cherif Pasha's Chamber of Deputies, and the existing Legislative Council and General Assembly established by Lord Dufferin. The work will contain numerous citations from official documents and some use will be made of Mr. Wilfrid Scawen Blunt's testimony. The pamphlet will end with a statement and elaboration of the proposals for the amendment of the constitution, recently put forward by Sheikh Aly Youssef, of "Al Moayad," and Hafiz Effendi Awad, of "Al Minbar." It is no doubt. in his advocacy of such changes that the author will arouse the most divergent views and encounter considerable opposition.

div.head: A RADICALS VISIT.
div.p: The Moderate Nationalists are looking for. ward with the greatest interest to the arrival in Egypt of Mr. Rutherford, the Radical Member of Parliament, who is due here early in January. He will carefully inspect the country and its institutions as his confrère, Mr. Robertson, M.P., did last year.

div.head: LECTURE ON EGYPT.
div.p: At one of the special evening lantern slide lectures held at the Annual Exhibition of the Royal Photographic Society of Great Britain Mr. G. K. Marshall A.RI B.A. gave a description of Ancient Egypt to a crowded audience, indicating the keen interest taken in this subject in London. The photographs displayed in connection with the first part of the Address were of various antiquities in Museums including the mummy of Rameses II., and the very early set of "bracelets made of turquoise and gold found by Professor Petrie upon the broken-oft arm of some lady's mommy. Several illustrations were also given of the funerary statuettes or doll models, of the domestics and agriculturalists preparing items for the sepulchral feast The most valuable pictures shown however were a series specially taken by the lecturer at Thebes including many of the temple of Karnak. One of these showed the scenes graven, and the hieroglyphic texts, upon the corridor of the temple at Elfa, a most difficult subject for photography because of the impossibility of placing the camera at a distance from the wall. The lecture itself was both learned and interesting and gave great satisfaction. It is to be hoped that soon an enlarged series of photographs of Egyptian Temples will be exhibited at these annual salons of the Photographic Society. The Cathedrals and Churches of Western Europe have been exhausted and the never yet equalled edifices of ancient Egypt should have their turn.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Lord and Lady Cromer have secured a boang at Naim, where Lord Cromer has found the sir most beneficial to bis health Pending the alterations to their new London house, Lord and Lady Cromer will remain in the No th.
Hussein Pasha Rushdi, Director General of the War Administration, will return from France in the middle of this month.

Early in January Mrs. Mackay, the wife of the Americain millionaire, accompanied by her daughter, Princess Colonda, and Countes Telfner, will come to Egypt and make an excursion up the Nile as far as the second Cataract.

Lady Roby Elliot, whose engagement to Lord Cromer's son we recently announced, is shortly returning to Calcutta to rejoin her parents. Since Lady Minto's return to Indix Lady Raby has been staying in Scotland with Lady Cromer. The date of her wedding with Lord Errington has not yet been fixed, but it is expected to take place next summer, and probably in London.
Mr. Williams, Inspector General of Irrigation for Lower Egypt, has arrived in Cairo returning from leave.
Professor Flinders Petrie, the well-known Egyptologist, leaves London for Egypt on the 10th inst.

div.head: ISLAMIC CONGRESS.
div.p: There was a fairly large assembly at the Grand Contigental Hotel to-night to attend the meeting convened by Shiekh . Aly Yosel, proprietor of "Al Moayad," with the object of preparing the way for an Islamic Congress. The meeting was timed to start at 9 p.m. and at that time a large crowd had gathered on the terrace of the hotel, and in the crush which resulted one of the glass panels of a door was broken.

Shiekh Aly Yusef first addressed the meeting briefly, explaining the object for which it had been called, and introducing the chief speaker of the evening, lainail Bey Goafrensky, who speaking in Turkish called upon the Mohamedans of the world to unite and follow the example of the other nations of the world in the pursuit of civilization and knowledge. The first endeavour of the Mamluwan world, should, he mid, be the formation of schools in every sphere where Mosalumans aiated, for this work a sum of one million and a hak mould be necessary. It is a large sum, where to into be obtained from the Mussluman himself. Let each man who had the welfare of his creed at heart subscribe his mito let the pin who smoked 10 cigarettes a day, reduce the number by balf and pat the money raised to the canine which would benefit the whole Mohamedin world.

The Christians he said had left the Mohamedan behind in every walk of life. The latter could hardly boost the ponension d a single steamship, or a single bank, and why, because the Mussloman was not alive to his duty, was not sufficiently united in bis endeavours, and was too content to follow a loul without attempting to rise to the same place as the other nations.
He quoted the nation of the Greeks who have, in losing hold of the older civilization common to the East, might hold of the new, and still holds position duong the power of the world.

div.head: THE RAILWAY CONFERENCE
div.p: LONDON, November 1.
The Railway Conference has been adjourned till to-day.
(Reuter)
London, November 1.

The railway chairmen and Mr. Lloyd George met again in conference this morning. The conference has now been adjourned till Wednesday when Mr. Lloyd George afterwards will receive representations of the Amalgamated Society of Railway Servants with a view to a possible settlement being arrived at

It is stated that Mr. Lloyd George regards the Directors concessions as most important and he is as hopeful as Mr. Bell of a compromise being come to. On the other hand, the advisory committee of the Amalgamated Society of Railway Servants after five hours deliberation this afternoon passed a resolution that in view of the Companies' refusal to meet their representatives there was no alternative but to carry out the mandate of the members revealed in the result of the ballot and to issue strike notice papers to the whole of railwaymen in the Kingdom,
Mr. Bell, in the course of an interview, said that the papers would be issued to members of the union and non-members alike. (Reuter)

div.head: THE GERMAN SCANDALS.
div.p: BERLIN, November 1.
The "Frankfurter Zeitung' states that the public prosecutor has begun proceedings Against Prince Philip Eulenberg and three ex-officers of high rank.
(Reuter)
BERLIN, November 1.

The Public Prosecutor has intervened in the Moltke Harden case and will prosecute Herr Harden for criminal libel. He explained that he abstained originally because he hoped that failing official action the case would be dropped and a public scandal avoided. He intervenes now considering that Count Moltke had in sufficient opportunity of justifying himself and because he desired to completely clear up the matter.
(Reuter)

div.head: A RUSSIAN PLOT.
div.p: ST. PETERSBURG, November 1.
Several military clerks have been arrested here owing to the revelation of a plot to blow up the whole military council, including the Minister of War, by a bomb at its weekly sitting.
(Reuter)

div.head: Sr. PETERSBURG, November 1.
div.p: Several employés of the War Ministry have been arrested in consequence of a plot to kill by boinbs all the members of the military council.
(Havas)

div.head: LORD CROMER AS AUTHOR.
div.p: London, November 2.
Macmillans will publish early next year a book on modern Egypt by Lord Cromer.
(Renter)

div.head: NEW BATTLESHIP.
div.p: LONDON, November 1.
The Admiralty has invited tenders for the construction of a third battleship which was included in the current estimates but postponed pending the result of the Hagne Conference.
(Reutor)

A Bulgarian band burned several houses in the Greek village Anastasia, near Zebna, and threw 5 persons into the flames.. (Reuter)

div.head: EGYPT'S TRADE
div.p: CHEMICAL MANURE IMPORTS.

A trade in Egypt which has been increasing, says the British Chamber of Commerce Bulletin, by leaps and bounds during the past three or four years, and which will undoubtedly continue to do so for some time to come, is the one dealing with the handling of artificial fertilisers. The accompanying statistics, which have been prepared from the Customs House returns, show that in 1902 the total imports of all artificial manures were 2,000 tons valued at LE. 13,000, whilst last year the figures were nearly 13,000 tons declared at over L.E. 122,000. For the first nine months of 1907 the deliveries totalled 7579 tons L.E. 76,907.

Apart from the influence of the Assouan Dam and other irrigation works in largely increasing the area of cultivable land, and so causing a bigger demand for manures, the main reason for the recent rapid growth in the trade is the fact that the native is now endeavouring to grow cotton once every two years instead of once in three, and, consequently, finds that he must return something to the land which will replace the nourishment taken out of it by thu cotton. When we remember the high figure the fellah pays for his land, whether he buys or rents it, coupled with the phenomenal price at which he has recently been able to dispose of his crop, we can readily understand that tho man will endeavour to squeeze cotton out of his fields as often as possible.

Prior to the introduction of artificial fertilisers, the credit for which being due almost entirely to the Khedivial Agricultural Society, the native mainly depended upon "Sabakh," that is to say the remains of old buildings villages and cemeteries for his manure. Such remains-generally in the form of small hills -were found all over the Delta, but they are gradually becoming appreciably scarcer, or too far away from the scenes of cultivation Other native manures are river and canal mud and stable refuse, but these, together with "Sabakh," are totally insufficient to meet the requirements of the country, and we therefore scarcely think we are wide of the mark in say. ing that chemical manure imports are likely to still further largely develop

In the Nota published by the financial Adviser to the Egyptian Government on the subject of the budget for 1906, attention was drawn to the fact that, while the area under cotton cultivation had steadily grown during the past few years, there had been no increase in total crop productions, the quality also having left much to be desired. A word of caution was given to those cultivators who were then growing cotton on the same land every two years, and who did not also pay sufficient attention to the question of the seed.

In a similar Note a year later on the Budget for 1907, the Adviser said "Although the area devoted to cotton has steadily increased of late years, the total amount of the crop has scarcely varied, and it was feared that overcropping had seriously impaired the productivity of the soil.

"The record this year does not altogether bear on this theory. The present cotton season has proved very satisfactory. The total crop will probably exceed that of its predecessor by from one half to three-quarters of a million kantars."
A partial explanation of the improved state of affairs at the end of 1906 was, undoubtedly, the fact that imports of chemical manures in that year were 12,725 tons against only 6,200 tons in 1905.

For cotton, the native usually puts on each feddan (a little more than an acre) 200 kilos of superphosphates and from 80 to 90 kilos of nitrogenous fertilisers, of which about two thirds are nitrate of soda and one-third sulphate of ammonia. Manures in these proportions will cost about P.T 180 to P.T. 185 (£1.16.11 to £1.17.11) delivered to any railway station in Lower Egypt
For wheat, the cultivator uses from 90 to 100 kilos of nitrate of soda per feddan. He can obtain this delivered to any station in Lower Egypt from P.T. 115 to P.T. 120 (£1.3.7 to £1.4.7) per feddan.
The prices of chemical manures vary considerably from time to time, but the following may be taken as average rates :
Nitrate of soda £ 12.10.- per ton c. i. 1. Alexandria,
Sulphate of Ammonia £ 13 to £ 13.5.per ton c. i. f. Alexandria.
Superphosphates $ 3.2.--to £ 3.6.----per ton c. i. f. Alexandria,
The above prices include the packing of the manyres in double sacks.
The quality of superphosphates imported is that containing from 16 to 18 per cent. of phos. phorio acid water and citrate soluble..

Owing to the very small Egyptian demand prior to last year, it was found cheaper and more convenient to bring the nitrate of soda from Chili to Belgium and then trans-ship to Alexandria According to requirements. This largely accounts for the foot that in 1905, Belgium had practically the whole of the Bgyptian trade. In 1906, the sales having increased so enormously, the Khedivial Agricultural Society of Cairo chartered two vessels and brought full cargoes (besides having part cargoes on their ships) direct from Chili to Alexandria, and the same process is being repeated this year.

Belgium is the principal source of supply for superphosphates, the manures being actually prepared in that country. Glasgow also ships & few superphosphates, but Antwerp does nearly the whole of the trade.
In the case of Sulphate of Ammonia, the main port of shipment is Glasgow, after which comes Antwerp.

Practically the only manures fnanofaotared in Egypt are those turned out by the Cairo Sewage Transport Co. such as "Poudrette" and other sewage prodnots. The Company also works ap various slaughter house products such as dried blood, powdered hoof and horn and ground bones. When these were first pot on the market some years ago, the Company had great difficulty in selling them, as the dative did not appreciate the value of artificial manares, and, moreover, was not in a good enough financial position to incur the necessary expense. These difficulties, however, have now been overcome, thanks to the work done by the Khedivial Agricultural Society in edu. cating the natives in the use of fertilisers, and Also to the fact that the fellaheen can dow afford to pay for the same.

With regard to the Khedivial Agricultural Society of which mention has already been madle, we may say that this body has interested itself in the distribution of chemical manures, during the past six or seven years. With the object to assisting the Society in this work, the Government between September and December 1906 lent them £100,000 at 2% per annum interest

Speaking on the above matter in his report for the year 1906 Lord Cromer said that the whole of the £100,000 "was employed and reimbursed to the Society, which was thus in a position to repay the Government. In view of the large amount of money required in the future, the Government has informed the Society that it is unable to advance further sums. The question thus becomes one of ordinary commerce. So long as the Governmentadvanced money to the Society at a low rate of interest, and the Society distributed manure at a profit of only 2 %, it was obviously impossible for commercial enter I prise to enter into competition with the Society,

In future the Society will not be able to carry I on the whole of this work as in the past. Com. merce will, it is hoped, gradually replace the Society, and, by selling at a reasonable price, will induce cultivators to obtain their supplies through this channel."

We may mention that the Egyptian Markets Ltd. have recently entered into the trade of supplying the natives with artificial manares. The Company which was established in 1898 with a capital of $175,000, runs official markets in 120 centres in Egypt and, therefore, possesses the necessary organization for distributing the fertilisers direct to the Arabs.

The imports of chemical manures are allowed into the country daty free (the only other instance of free entry here being books by parcel post) and special reduced rates are in force on the State Railways for carriage into the Interior. It will thus be seen that the Government is encouraging the native, as far as possible, to use chemical manures.
There is no monopoly for the import of artifi. cial fertilisers, and any manufacturer or mer: chant is that able to engage in the trade.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: There is no change in the weather conditions.

div.head: Notice to Advertisers
div.p: The "Egyptian Gazette" has given no advertising agency or company in Egypt any monopoly or exclusive right to act as advertising agents on its behalf. Advertisements of ever description are received at the offices of the "Gazette" from advertisers direct.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: (From our own CORRESPONDENT).
London, October 23.

Lieutenant Colonel J. M. Jones, Royal Army Medical Corps, who, as already intimated in these notes, has been appointed P. M. O., in. Egypt, is a very clever medico of mnch experience in many lands, particularly in the tropics, for such as the Mediterranean foxer, etc. As a çivil surgeon, he saw a great deal of service in the Zulu War, 1879-80, for which he holds the medal with clasp.

Lieutenant C. P. Heywood. 2nd Battalion Coldstream Guards, has been selected for service with the Egyptian Army. Mr. Heywood has worn the bearskin since Augnet, 1899, and he served with the Guards Brigade in the South African War through the fighting in Orange River Colony and the Transwaal to Pretoria via the battlefields of Vet River, Zand River, Johannesburg and Pretoria, and later on in the actions of Diamond Hill and Belfast and the minor affairs in Cape Colony down to the close of the war (Queen's medal with five clasps, King's medal with two clasps). He was latterly adjutant of the 2nd Battalion.

When Captain S. G. Roe, Royal Inniskilling Fasiliers, now on the way home from Egypt, relieves Captain D. G. H. Auchinleck in the adjatancy of the 4th Battalion, at Onagh, the latter will be posted to a company in the 1st Battalion, Crete.
A vacant second lieutenant in the Royal Dublin Fusiliers has been filled by the promotion of Corporal F. T. L. Friend, a smart young subaltern of the Leinster Regiment, to a compilation.
On return to regimental duty from service with the Khedive's army, Captain M. J. Hamilton, Lancashire Fusiliers, has been posted to the 2nd Battalion, Fermoy.

Major C. S. Wilson, Royal Engineers, who has just been appointed for duty to Egypt, will embark for Alexandria on the 2nd prox. Major Wilson has spent over twenty one years in the Scientific Corps, and has had considerable experience of Bastern Africa, having been engaged on the Anglo-Portuguese Boundary Commission, 1892-95, and 1898-99. He was with the Royal Engineers in the South African War, 1899-1902, earning a mention in deg. patohen, and the Queen's medal with three clasps, and the King's medal with two clasps for his services in Orange River Colony and Cape Colony.

Nearly all hands of the "Green Howards," at Aldershot, have submitted themselves to inoculation against enterio in view of their approaching tour in Egypt and India, and lectures in hygiene have been given to all ranks. It is hoped by these means to minimise the effects of this tropical scourge.

In January next, Captain J. G. Lawrence, Army Pay Corps, will embark for Egypt for a tour of duty there. Captain Lawrence originally entered the Royal Irish Regiment ten years ago, and transferred in 1903 to the financial branch of the service. He has the Tirah Expedition, 1897 (medal with clasp) to his credit.
The move of the 6th Inniskilling Dragoons' Reserve Squadron from Ballincollig to Hounslow has been postponed till the 23rd January,

The 3rd Battalion King's Royal Rifle Corps, Aldersbot, is getting ready for its tour of foreigy, hervice, its first station being Crose, for where it will embark on the 18th Pebenary i next. Nearly all hands have been inoculated against the enterio, fiend preparatory to.going. eastwards. The battalion, which will become on the strength of the Malta oomraad during - its stay in Crete, has been on home service. since the close of the South African warand. previous to that was on home service from 1891, when it returned from, Gibraltan It was stationed at Kilkenny when the Boer war broke out, was mobilised and sent to the front, where it greatly, distinguished itself in Lyttleton's Brigade at the battles of. Colenso and Spion Kop, and the relief of Ladysmith Its Ist Battalion is at Cairo and Khartoum.

Probably no more striking proof of the great changes that have taken place in the Bapino's. naval strategy can be adduced than that there are ng battleships farther from home water than the MediterranogR. 4 very short time ago there were, cruisers and battleships in almost every part of the work.rendy to look after the interests of the country and render assistance to its people if necessary. There was no-possibility of a Jamaican incident. That many of our naval officer are not satisfied with this state of incorrethont saving and amongst them is Commodore Sir. George J. & War render, Bart., c.Y.O. Ce commanding the East Indies Squadron, which links up the Mediterrapsen Flex sleep Rate the Cape and Australia. It is understood that Sir George has made very strong representations to the Admiralty on the subject of strengthen.
It is expected that the battleship "Goliath" will be despatched to the Mediterranean about the beginning of the New Year.

The old line of battleship "Asia," 80 guns, which flew the flag of Admiral Sir Edward Codrington commanding the British, French and Russian Fleets at the battle of Navarino against the Turkish and Egyptian Fleeta--in the course of which the latter were practically annihilated on the 20th October 1827, is to be sold out of the navy it is understood, or broken up.

Today, Lord Charles Beresford has a fleet of 110 battleships cruisers and smaller ships operating under his orders in the North Sea. It is the mightiest naval demonstration--for that is really what it is-ever sent from one scores to prove that in all verity "Britannia rules the waves." No war correspondents have beep allowed with the Fleet, the tactics and operations of which are of a confidential nature.

The Army Council has just issued a very important circular in connection with the musketry season of the regular and ancillary forces. From this it appears that the average in shooting in the cavalry rose from 171 to 176, and in the infantry from * 169 to 173, the improvement being attributed to the new wind gauge which came into use last year. Recruit training was marked by improvement, particularly At the local depots. Instruction in firing from behind cover is to receive greater attention during the barrack square stage, and the soldier is to be farther looked after in regard to his physical development in order to fit him for prolonged spells of firing. On the whole, it is considered that firing is too fast. The manual lays down 15 rounds per minute, but 10 is considered to be a good general average.

Aprop 9 of nával gannery, it sometimes happens that the man behind the gun is not to blame when the sbot fails to hit the target. Recently, the very bad shooting of the battleship "Hannibal" provoked some sharp comment, but an investigation of the sights of the big guns showed that they were practically useless, and no gunner could hit the mark by their aid. Stringent instructions have just been

island are the proper protection to gun sights under every circumstance. In future the sights are to be covered constantly, save when in age, or cleaning, with stout canvas protectors. Coaling is particularly severe on the delicate mechanism of the sights, Aa the gritty particles force their way into the bearings and adjustments of the working party, and of congress that affects their economy. Rast, too, is fatal, and is to be prevented.
FATAL SEA SICKNESS

A commercial traveller named Thomas North died last week on board one of the Great Western stearners on a package from Jersey to Guernsey. North, who was about sixty-five years of age, travelled for a firm of London woollen manufacturers, Death is attri. buted to heart failure or cerebral hemorrhage, brought on by sea-sickness.

div.head: REVUE COMMERCIALE
div.p: Coton.

La séance de Samedi matin qui a inauguré la semaine a été ferme au début, mais l'absence d'acheteurs sérieux dès que des offres de vente se sont présentées a provoqué une réaction et la clôture a eu lieu en tendance faible.

Landi, avant l'ouverture et à la suite d'une propagande à tont career faite par des personnes cherchant à faire croire an public que la récolte ne saurait jamais dépasser les 6 1/4 millions de Cantars, on s'attendait à voir les cours se raffermir de non veau ; mais, dès que les affsires ont commence, la désillusion a été complete : la corbeille s'est trop facilement rappelée que 5 ou 6 jours aoparavant les mê. mes personnes, plume en main, lui avaient prouvé que le minimum à attendre était de 7 millions et que, par conséquent, il ne fallait pas prendre pour parole d'évangile ce qui en somme pouvait n'avoir comme canse qu'un simple changement de position à la suite de la baisse qui s'était produite dans le courant de In somaine précédente. Quoi qu'il en soit, le fait est que la matinée a été des plus froides et qu'elle a fini en baisse de 3/16 de tallari.
Pendant l'après-midi, la sitnation est restée la même, mais le lendemain la faiblesse s'est accentuée et a fait fléchir le Novembre à 191/16.

Mercredi et Jeudi ont été par contre deux journées de reprise, mais comme rien ne justi fiait l'amélioration qu'on tichait de consolider, le maximum pratiqué hier matin, soit 19 3/8, n'a pa etre maintenu et le soir le Novembre a été affiché à 19 7/32.

On remarquait un désir intense de réaliser et cette impression était tellement vraie qu'aujourd'hui et malgré les exportations dépassant les prévisions, la tenge du marché a été pitoyable et que la semaine a fini sur la cote de-19 1/32 pour Novembre, soit tout bonne. ment en perte de 9/16 sur Vendredi dernier.

Ce n'est certainement pas la un brillant résultat pour ceux qui veuleot la hausse A tout prix et qui ont peut-être sérieusement cru pouvoir l'imposer par des moyens factices; mais ce qu'il y a de plus mauvais encore, c'est la tendauce qui ce soir semble être franchement pour la baisse. Les positions des haussiers sont trop chargées et l'on dirait presque qu'il n'y a plas moyen pour eux de continuer à absorber tout ce que le commerce vend en contrats contre ses achats en disponible. Du reste il y a limite à tout, surtont quand tout le monde n'a pas encore fini avec ses difficultés financières, témoin certains incidents, sans con séquences graves, dans le règlement de la dernière liquidation et qui n'ont pu être tenus aussi secrets qu'on l'aurait vouln.

Cette semaine on a inauguré les affaires sur Mai avea 11/16 de report sur Mars, et comme il fallait s'y attendre, la spéculation n'a rien eu de plus prossé que de se jeter sur cette échéance, pour laquelle elle n'a pas à envisager l'éventualité d'une filière comme cela semble etre le cas pour Novembre courant. Cette façon d'agir a eu pour effet de porter le report à 13/16 et de permettre à quelques négociants de consentir des transferts de Novembre à Mai avec 2 1/4 tallaris. - C'est la rente habituelle que les arbitragistes empochent au détriment de Ik spéculation qui ne veut pas voir qu'à opérer dans ces conditions il n'y a que de l'argent à perdre, à moins que des circonstances de l'autre monde ne viennent prodaire une hausse formidable par la suite et suffisante pour offrir une compensation à ces sacrifices et laisser en fin de compte un bénéfice quelconque à celui qui court tous ces risques. C'est toat simplement absurde et ce n'est pas quand le coton égyptien est tenu à 10 ou 11 tallaris au-dessus de l'américain que l'on peut espérer de ces miracles !

Pour ce qui est de la filature, son abstention est toujours complete: l'importance des exportations actuelles est d'ailleurs la meilleure preuve que pour le moment elle est approvisionnée et qu'elle peut pour quelque temps persisterdans a réserve.

Les nouvelles de l'intérieur au sujet de la récolte sont un peu contradictoires, mais prenant l'enseinble des informations que l'on reçoit de tous les côtés, le diable ne serait pas après tout si noir qu'on a voulu le dire. Il est vrai que les idées de 7 1/4 et même de 7 mil. lions comme minimum perdent du terrain, mais nous avons entendu dire par des personnes on ne peut plus compétentes et à même d'être bien renseignéer, que ce serait une profonde errenr que de croire à une récolte infe. rieure à 634.

Et puis comment veut-on on'une ricolte soit cléficitaire ni, avec des arrivages par enn entravés et en retard de 15 ou de 20 jours, et avec une pénurie d'argent qui ralentit les transactions à l'intérieur, les recettes sont à ce jour de 110.000 cantarsupériears A cenx de l'ann'e paesde à la même date 1

Nous donnons plus loin les détails de la dernière enchère des Domaines ; les résultats ne sont pas aussi bons que ceux obtenus dans les ventes précédentes, mais il paralt qu'en dehors de l'état du marché, il y a cette fois une question de qualité qui doit entrer en ligne de compte à la comparaison.

Les avis d'Amérique varient chaque jour, mais ni l'annonce d'une amélioration sensible dans la situation financière, ni la nouvelle d'une tempête sévissant à Galveston, ni la prétendue tendance à diminuer les estimations de la récolte n'ont eu le don de provoquer une reprise durable. Par contre, ce que l'on sait positivement, c'est que malgré le bon marché il n'y a aucun engouement de la part de la consommation et que la grève des portefaix n'est pas encore terminée. Ce dernier point explique du coup l'infériorité des in sight comparative Inent à l'année dernière d cette même période.
Notre marché da disponible est faible depuis quelques jours et la marehandise continue à prendre de plus en plus le chemin des magasins des vendeurs. Pour les besoins de

leurs embarquements, les exportnteurs semblent avoir ce qu'il leur faut et comme les nouvelles affaires font défaut et que rien ne presse s'il y a des engagements pour des époques éloignées, ce ralentissement dans la demande s'explique d'autant plus facilement que les banques ne sont pas si larges à consentir de nouvelles Avances.

Pour ce qui est des prix il y a grande irré. gularité et tandis que certaines qualités ont suivi les contrats, d'autres en ont différé et c'est précisément ponr cela que les différences en moins pour la semaine dans la cote officielle de ce matin vont de 1.8 à 1 tallari.
Les expéditions de la semaine ont été supé. rieures aux prévisions avec leur total de 30000 balles contre 34000 l'année dernière.

On prétend qu'on a anticipé certains ernbargnements et que la semaine prochaine le cas sera le même, ce qui nous vandra pent-être une quantité plos forte que la période corres. pondante en 1906 et cela malgré l'interruption des affaires à l'occasion du Bairam tombant jeudi prochain. Du reste, il paralt avéré que les Banques pressent leurs clients d'expédier un moment plus tôt et qn'à cause des nécessités de son trafic, plus d'un exportateur envoie à Liverpool et à Manchester en dépôt contre avances par les banques anglaises ce qui en d'entres temps n'aurait été expédié qu'en temps et lieu.

Liverpool a été peu actif pour les Egyptiens disponibles et sous le rapport des prix, la cote se trouve réduite de 1/16 à 10 1/8. - Les futurs aussi ont snbi quelques points de recnl et le cours du Janvier ce soir n'est que de 9 49/64.
Les américains de leur côté n'ont pas été bien actifs et comme cote le spot se trouve joliment maltraité avec la perte de 21 points qué montre la cote de 5.93.
Les futora, par contre, ont eu relativement one meilleure finale avec les cours de 5.58 pour
Février et de 5.57 pour le Mars. Avril, le recul dans ces conditions n'étant que de 3 à 4 points.
P.8. - Deux mots sur Novembre 1908. Il a donné lieu à beancoup de cris et peu d'affaires. Dn reste il n'y a que de rares amateurs pour cette échéance qui cloture à 20 tallaris.

Graines de Coton Les arrivages de la semaine ont été importants et supérieurs tant cenx de l'année dernière qu'aux besoins courante des exportateurs ; aussi ne fantil pas s'étonner si le calme a fini par prendre le dessus pour ce qui concerne le disponible. Le dernier cours a été de P.T. 72.
En contrats, les affaires sont toujours sporadiques, mais les cours sont fermes quoiqne en réaction après le dernier mouvement de hausse que nous avons eu.
Hull est en baisse À £ 7.1/3d, ce qui est Attribué à la baisse des huiles en Amérique pour les livraisons à partir de Janvier
Les tourteaux sont calmes et à des prix peu rémunérateurs.

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE
div.p: Alexandrie, le 1er Novembre.

LA SEMAINE La séance de lundi a été presque pulle. On criait beaucoup, surtout les petites valeurs au rabais, mais les acheteurs faisaient défant. L'attention était concentrée sur la National Bank, l'Agricole, l'United et le Comptoir.

Le lendemain la corbeille a présenté l'aspect d'une séance d'été. Peu de monde, la plupart assis ou dósceuvrés et quelques raros transactions en titres secondaires, United Lands, Rita Hotels et Delta Land. Les valeurs dirigeantes et en général toutes celles dépassant un certain prix ont été négligées Bien que la plupart des agents se soient tenus sur ane predeute réserve pour ne pas casser inutilement les cours en l'absence de toute contre partie, il s'est produit cependant une dépression partielle, provenant de l'insistance de quelques détenteurs tmp prenses de réaliser. La baisse et l'inaction ont rainené la majeure partie des spéculateurs à me plus joste notion de la réalité et ils avouent enfin que les affaires ne vont pas. Il était temps de s'en apercevoir

Josques-là pourtant on n'avait ici que pen ressenti les effets de la crise américaine ; mais les dépêches de Londres nons ayant transmis mercredi une baisse notable des valeurs égyptiennes simultanément avec une élévation substantielle dn taux privé d'escompte, on & constaté ce jourlàm notre bourse une afluence inusitée de vendeurs en quête d'une contrepartie : vaines recherches d'ailleurs, restées pour la plupart sans résultat. On a traité seolement, et des cours plus bas, quelques Comptoir, Delta Land, National Bank, Helouan et Estates.

Hier enfin, bien que notre marché ait été loin d'être bon, il n'a cependant pas été aussi mauvais dans l'ensemble que ne le faisait entrevoir la nouvelle dépression des valeurs égyptiennes au Stock Exchange. Ce qui de veut pas dire que les affaires aient été plug nombreuses que la veille, ou que des acheteurs se soient présentés, mais simplement que las intéressés ont réussi par leur réserve à maintenir les cours en dépit d'offres nombreuses tombant dans le vide. Les transactions se sont limitées, et encore dans des proportions regtreintes, aux Comptoir, Estates, Fanous, Delta Land, United, Agricole et National Bank

Aujourd'hui, à l'occasion de la fete de la "Toussaint, les courtiers se sont octroyés un jour de chômage, de sorte qu'avec le repos hebdomadaire do samedi et du dimanche la place jouit de trois jours de répit, qui peuvent donner le temps à quelque bonne nouvelle de nous parvenir du dehors.
Aux ENCHERRA PUBLIQUES

Dans le courant de la semaine, il a été vendu aux enchères publiques 100 Panous (Land Investment & Building) à 13/64, 50 actions anciennes Comptoir Financier à 2 13/16, 25 Crédit Franco-Egyptien à 4 5/32 et 25 Levico à 8/8. D'autres enchères auront lieu prochainement.

LES PLUCTUATIONS DE LA COTE Il est bien évident qu'avec une allure dépri. mée comme celle que nous avons eue les cours cont du fléchir. Sur une soixantaine de valeurs inscrites à la cote officielle de notre bourse, 81 sont en baisse et 4 seglement en hausse, les autres demeurant stationnaires aux prix anterieurs.
Disons tout de suite que les 4 titres phéno. mènes sont les Markets en gain de 8 pence, l'Obligation nouvelle Crédit Poncier de i Irano, la Delta Land de 1/32, et les Splendid Hotels de 1/16.

Parmi les titres en rétrogradation, on constate 3/4 de baisse en National Bank, 1/2 en Alexandria Water, 5/8 en Deira, 8/4 en Be. héra, 1/2 en Nongovich Hotels. Au-dessous de ces moins-values respectables gravitent celles de la Delta Light 1/4, des Privilégiées Tramways d'Alexandrie 5 franes, des Jouissances Eaux du Caire 5 francs, de la Differed Delta 1/4, de l'Urbaine 1/4, da Comptoir Finanvier 7/32 l'action et 3/16 la part de fondateur, de la Building Lands 1/4, et du Crédit FrancoEgyptien 3/16.

Les autres rédactions sont peu appréciables : 1/8 en Agricole, Ramleh, Land Bank et fondateur United Landa, 3/32 en Estates, 1/16 en Union Foncière, Panous et Levioo, 1 frano en Privilégiée Biere d'Alexandrie ot Cassa di Sconto, 2 france en Obligations anciennes Cré. lit Foncier, Sacreries et Banque d'Orient, 550 centimes en Banque d'Athènes, 3 pence en Cotton Mills et Ordinary Khedivial Mail, 9 penoe en Salt & Soda.

Sur tout le reste de la cote il n'y a pas de changement à signater. On voit que si une cer taine catégorie de valeurs a été assez durement #prouvée, l'ensemble a fait preave d'on sontien relatif. Il est vrai que certains attribuent cette apparente fermeté a l'absence à peu près complete de transactions ; dans ce cas la forte de préciation des seuls titres immédiatement réalisables est tout-a-fait compréhensible.
MARCHÉS EUROPÉENS

An Stock-Exolange la Daïra recule de 3/4, la National Bank de 6/8, l'Agricole de 1/8 et| la Delta Light de 1/4; ayeu pet d'affaires. En revanche, l'Unifiée Egyptienne avance de 1/4 et le Consolide Anglais de 7/8.
A Paris, l'action Credit Foncier Egyptien trograde de 7 francs et la Land Bank of Egypt de 1 franc, tandis que le Crédit Franco-Egyp: tien progresse de 1 franc et la Rente Française de 38 points.
Il est incontestable que cette semaine le Stook-Exchange a ereroe one influence sur notre place, on les valeur dirigeantes ont

reactionné gradnellerneat avte Londres. Mais les correspondances arrivées d'Angleterre nous rigna lant que la baisse particulière des valeurs égyptiennek ent bel et bien nocasionnée par des offres provenant d'Egypte. Ce sont donc bien les porteurs égyptiens goi jettent leurs paquets sur le marché et il importe peu qu'ils vendent ici ou à Londres. Ce sont tonjours enx qui déterminent la baisse.

LA SITUATION MONÉTAIT Les exportations d'or de la Banque d'Angleterre ont sériensement ébranld sa réserve qui, à 39 7/8, se trouve diminuée de 7 3/8%. C'est pentrêtre la plus forte secousse qu'elle ait reça cette année. Aussi, après avoir longtemps hésité à mayınenter le taux de son escompte, espérant toujours que les affaires s'arrangeraient en Amérique, elle a été obligée hier A la suite de la crise de le porter d'un coup de 4 1/2

5 1/2 % pour défendre son etichisse. Et l'on s'est inême pas sûr qu'elle ne doive pas l'arginenter encore prochainement : tout 86I pendra de l'allure qne prendront les événements là New-York. La Banque d'Allemagne avait
déjà au début de la semaine élevé son taux de 15 à 8 1,2%

En ce qui concerne la crise américaine, bien qu'on ne puisse encore rien dire de definitif à ce sujet, cependant il est arrivé ce qui arrive presque toujours av lendemain d'une paniqne. De sang-froid on a constaté que la situation, quoique d'une exceptionnelle gravité, n'était pas aussi désespérée qu'on l'avait era tout d'abord L'intervention prompta et énergique du Sporétaire du Trésor, ainsi que lle des milliardaires américains, n'a pas été sans prodoire une certaine détente. Il n'empêche que la crise existe toujours et que New-York anra sans doute besoin de beaucoup de numéraire. C'est ce qui a porté la Banque d'Angleterre a augmenter son taux d'escompte, comme nons venons de le dire.

loi la situation n'est pas changée ; la spécolation suit avec une inquiétude bien naturelle les diverses pbases de la crise monétaire mondiale. De l'issue de la lutte dépend en partie son avenir à elle. Elle n'a pas réussi jusqu'à maintenant à se décharger de quantités considérables de son stock, et si l'aggravation de la crise devait occasionner une accentuation notable de la baisse, il est clair qu'elle se tronverait engagée dans de nouvelles complications dont le résultat ne pent qne difficilement être prévu.

QUELQUES INFORMATIONS FINANCIEREN Vendredi passé les actions de la Delta Land avaient déchi sur le bruit que le Gouvernement aurait décidé d'établir & Toursh le champ d'épandage. Si cela était, la propriété que possède la Société à Maadi perdrait, en effet, beaucoap de sa valeur. Mais nous tenons de M. Henriques, directeur général de la Delta Land, de passage à Alexandrie, que la Société a été définitivement informée que les égouts du Caire ne seraient pas dirigés sur Tourah.

On sait quelles rumeur circulent depuis quelque temps sur le compte de l'United Rgyptian Lands. Or, conformément à l'information que nous avons déjà publiée, la direction nous informne officielleinent que le conseil d'administration est arrivé à des accords pour le paiement du solde de son domaine de Komel Akhdar et de la propriété de l'ile de Rodah. des accords délivrent l'United Egyptian Lands de toute pression financière et lui assurent les fonds indispensables au développement de ses Affaires.
La Sidi Salem Estates a encore vendu ces jours-ci 70 feddans environ de sa propriété de Sidi Salem à des prix variant de 75 á 95 livres.

div.head: “INVESTMENTS.”
div.p:
“Investments” introduces, in an entirely original manner, new and important methods for the employment of and the means of obtaining capital. Among the
SPECIALLY CONTRIBUTED ARTICLES
are “Stock Markets and How to Profit by Them”; “Theory of Successful Speculation”; “How to start an Account” ; “The Advantages of ‘Call Options’”; “Contangoing Mining and Industrial Securities” ; “How to Invest in Mines”; “American Rails, with Points for Operators in Yankees”; “The Purchase of Investment Securities by Instalments” ; “General Principles for Investors” ; “Rules for Investors in Mines”; “General Principles for Speculators”; “Stock Exchange Terms,” being a glossary for Market Operators; “Stock Exchange Parlance”; “Insurance, as a Means of Making, Raising, and Saving Money,” and “Colonial Building Land: Its Great Possibilities.”
“Investments” (148 pages) sent Post Free on mentioning “Egyptian Gazette.”

div.head: Administration des Chemins de fer de l'Etat Egyptien
div.p: AVIS

L'Administration des Chemins de fer et Télégraphes de l'Etat a l'honneur de porter à la connaissance du Pablio qu'une enchère publique, par voie de Kaimat Monaksa, sera tenue le lundi vingt cing novembre prochain, de 10 heures du matin à midi, au Service Central des Magasins de Boulac (Caire) pour l'entreprise du factage, arrimage, chargement et déchargement des Charbons aux dépots de Gabbary, des Quais de Gabbary, Tanta, Zagazig, Anaber, Boulac, Pont Limoun, Boulac-DAcrour, Wasta, Sohag et Louxor, pendant l'année 1903, conformément aux conditions qui régissent cette entreprise et qui peuvent être consultées au Bureau de Mr. le Chef du Service Central des Magasins à Boulac (Caire), chaque jour de neuf heures du matin à une heure p m. les Dimanches et jours fériés exceptés.
Pour être admis à concourir, le soumissionnaire devra, au préalable, verser la Caisse Centrale de l'Administration an Caire, une somme de vingt Livres Egyptiennes à titre de
dépôt provisoire. Le soumissionnaire déclaré adjudicataire devra parfaire cette somme jus qu'à concurrence de cinquante Livres Egyptiennes à titre de garantie pour l'exécution du contrat
Toute offre laite ou déposée ultériegrement au jour et à l'heure ci-dessus désignés ne sera pas prise en considération.
L'Administration ne s'engage pas accepter l'offre la plus basse, ni n'importe quelle offre. Elle se réserve le droit de diviser l'entreprise.
Le Caire, le 30 Octobra 1907. 31186-2-1

A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.

This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic
THERAPION No.3
than by any other known combination. So surely as it is taken in accordance with the printed directions accompanying it, will the shattered health be restored,
THE EXPIRING LAMP OF LIFE LIGHTED UP AFRESH,

and a new existence imparted in place of what had so lately seemed worn-out, "used up,” and valueless. This wonderful medicament is purely vegetable and innocuous, is agreeable to the taste —suitable for all constitutions and conditions, in either sex; and it is difficult to imagine a case of disease or derangement, whose main features are those of debility, that will not be speedily and permanently benefited by this never-failing recuperative essence, which is destined to cast into oblivion everything that had preceded it for this wide-spread and numerous class of human ailments.

div.head: Commercial & Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette."
div.p: The Commercial and Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette" is published at midday every Saturday in time for the Austrian Lloyd's mail. The supplement contains exhaustive and important reviews of the cotton, cotton seed, and stock and share markets, with all the latest statistics up to the evening of the preceding day, complete tabular forms of the various market fluctuations, and the copies of the official telegrams of the Liverpool Cotton Association, etc., etc. Subscription for one year P.T. 100 (inclusive of postage in Egypt for abroad the postage is P.T. 10 extra). For Further particulars apply to the Manager the "Egyptian Gazette."
